syllabus:
**Approaches to Literary Works**

文學作品導讀

**Fall 2020**

Instructor: Jessie Shao 邵毓娟                                        Email: ycshao@ntnu.edu.tw

Office: Cheng 808                                                              Tel: 77491786

**I. Goals:**

The goal of this course is to provide students with a reasonably compact introduction to the study and appreciation of fiction, poetry, and drama. The selected literary works are studied in terms of basic elements such as plot, character, setting, point of view, theme, symbolism so as to enhance students’ ability in meaningful reading of literature and critical thinking. Students will be introduced to a number of critical concepts and approaches so as to heighten their sensibility to appreciate the cultural, socio-political, and philosophical dimensions of literary expressions.

**II. Required Textbook:**

Kelly J. Mays ed. _The Norton Introduction to Literature._ New York: Norton, 2016. 12th edition. (or 2019. 13th edition.)

**III. Tentative Syllabus:**

**Week 1 (Sep. 16):** Orientation

Topic: What is literature? And what is fiction? (See “Basic Elements of Fiction.”) **Week 2** **(Sep. 23):** 

Elements of Fiction: Narration (敘事) and Point of View (敘事觀點)

Topic: Media Mediation and Modern Life

Assigned Reading: “Cathedral” by Raymond Carver (p.32/p.28)

**Week 3** **(Sep. 30):** Elements of Fiction: Plot (情節); Theme (主題/主旨)

Topic: Conformism and Individuality

Assigned Reading: “A & P” by John Updike (p.163/p.163)

**Week 4 (Oct. 7):**

Topic: Life and Writing

Assigned Reading: “A Conversation with My Father” by Grace Paley (p.67/p.50)

**Week 5 (Oct. 14):** Elements of Fiction: Setting (場景)

Topic: Cultural Identity and Self-Identity

Assigned Readings: “A Pair of Tickets” by Amy Tan (p.302/p.293)

**Week 6 (Oct. 21):** Elements of Fiction: Character (人物)

Topic: Racial Identity and Self-identity 

Assigned Reading: “Recitatif” by Toni Morrison (p.238/p.230)

**Week 7 (Oct. 28):** Elements of Fiction: Symbol (象徵) and Figurative Language

Topic: Conflict and Initiation Stories (啟蒙故事) 

Assigned Reading: “Araby” by James Joyce (p.168/p.288)

**Week 8 (Nov. 4):**

 Topics: Initiation Stories; Gender and Subjectivity 

Assigned Reading: “Boys and Girls” by Alice Munro (p.152/p.152)

**Week 9 (Nov. 11):**  **Mid-term Exam**

**Week 10 (****Nov. 18****):** 

Film-Viewing: _Stranger than Fiction_

**Week 11 (Nov. 25):**

Topic: Cross-Cultural Encounters and Conflicts

Assigned Reading: “Interpreter of Maladies” by Jhumpa Lahiri  (p.446/p.491)

**Week 12 (Dec. 2):**

Topic: Liminal Experience and Black Identity  

Assigned Reading: “Sonny’s Blues” by James Baldwin (p.432/p.91)

**Week 13 (****Dec. 9****):**

Critical Casebook: The Author’s Work as Context: Flannery O’Connor 

Topic: Self-consciousness, Violence, and Truth

Assigned Reading: “Everything that Rises Must Converge” by Flannery O’Connor (p.495/p.540)

**Week 14 (Dec. 16)**:

Topic: Faith and Morality

Assigned Reading: “A Good Man Is Hard to Find” by Flannery O’Connor (p.470/p.516)

**Week 15 (Dec. 23)**: 

Topic: Paternalism and Gender Formation

Assigned Reading: “A Rose for Emily” by William Faulkner (p.628/p.658)

**Week 16 (Dec. 30)**:

Topic: Desire and Female Subjectivity

Assigned Reading: Chapter 8: Cultural and Historical Contexts: Women in Turn-of-the-Century America; “The Story of an Hour” by Kate Chopin (p.523/p.568); “The Yellow Wallpaper” by Charlotte Perkins Gilman (p.526/p.571)

**Week 17 (Jan. 6): Final Exam**

**Week 18 (Jan. 13): Individual Conference**

**IV. Requirements:**

1.  It is advised that you finish each reading assignment in advance of class meeting. 
2.  Follow basic classroom etiquette rules: Be punctual for class and send a notice to the instructor in advance when you cannot attend a class meeting.
3.  Attendance and participation are important. Discussing these texts with the instructor and your peers will enhance your ability in the understanding and appreciation of literary works. Your responses and questions will help facilitate more discussion and reflection on the assigned readings.
4.  Assignments:

(1) Individual work: Students are expected to take a weekly online quiz based on the assigned reading.

(2) Group work: Students are expected to work with their group members on the given topics so as to facilitate class discussion on the assigned reading.

1.  There are two exams scheduled for this semester: Midterm and Final.

**V. Grading Policy:** Your grade will be given based on your performance on the following aspects: 1. Individual Work: Attendance, participation, and weekly quizzes 30%; 2. Group Work 30%; 3. Exams 40%.
